articles.headline: Sweden Turns to a Promising Power Source, With Flaws
articles.snippet: Wind energy is coming under scrutiny, not just from hostile neighbors but from energy experts who question its reliability as a source of power.
articles.abstract: Wind energy is coming under scrutiny, not just from hostile neighbors but from energy experts who question its reliability as a source of power.
articles.lead_paragraph: MALMO, Sweden — Steadying himself on the heaving foredeck of an inspection ship recently, his face flecked by spray, Arne Floderus pronounced it a good day for his new offshore wind farm.

articles.headline: Japanese Shift Cash Out of U.S. Investments
articles.snippet: Many Japanese investors are quitting American investments, in a move that is altering global capital flows and helping to weaken the dollar.
articles.abstract: Many Japanese investors are quitting American investments, in a move that is altering global capital flows and helping to weaken the dollar.
articles.lead_paragraph: TOKYO, Nov. 22 — Many in Japan are starting to speak of “quitting America,” but they are not talking about a rise in anti-American political fervor. Rather, they mean a move away from American investments that is altering global capital flows and helping to weaken the dollar.

articles.headline: Megachurches Add Local Economy to Their Mission
articles.snippet: The business interests of megachurches include aviation subsidiaries and investment partnerships.
articles.abstract: The business interests of megachurches include aviation subsidiaries and investment partnerships.
articles.lead_paragraph: In Anchorage early in October, the doors opened onto a soaring white canvas dome with room for a soccer field and a 400-meter track. Its prime-time hours are already rented well into 2011.
articles.byline: By Diana B. Henriques and Andrew W. Lehren

articles.headline: In Reversal, Safe Is Risky, Risky Is Safe
articles.snippet: Some of Wall Street’s safest institutions — or those that hoped to be perceived as safe — turned out not to be, while some perceived as risky are so far sailing through.
articles.abstract: Some of Wall Street’s safest institutions — or those that hoped to be perceived as safe — turned out not to be, while some perceived as risky are so far sailing through.
articles.lead_paragraph: For a long time, if there was a problem on Wall Street, Credit Suisse was not far away. From its high-flying mortgage desk that blew up in 1998 to its superstar technology team that promoted Internet stocks in the late 1990s, Credit Suisse could be counted on as an example of problems on Wall Street.

articles.headline: Where the Votes Are, So Are All Those Calories
articles.snippet: Presidential candidates frequently find themselves obliged to change their eating habits on the campaign trail.
articles.abstract: Presidential candidates frequently find themselves obliged to change their eating habits on the campaign trail.
articles.lead_paragraph: Running for president is like entering a competitive eating contest and a beauty pageant all at once. Candidates are expected to eat local specialties often and with gusto, yet still look attractive and fit.

articles.headline: Careers Give India’s Women New Independence
articles.snippet: Women who once would have moved straight from their parents’ houses to their husbands’ now live on their own.
articles.abstract: Women who once would have moved straight from their parents’ houses to their husbands’ now live on their own.
articles.lead_paragraph: BANGALORE, India — Not long ago, an Indian woman, even a working Indian woman, would almost always have moved from her parents’ house to her husband’s. Perhaps her only freedom would be during college, when she might live on campus or take a room for a year or two at what is known here as the working women’s hostel.

articles.headline: Insurers Shift Cost Burdens to Homeowners
articles.snippet: After years of taking losses on home insurance, insurers are increasingly making homeowners responsible for repairs and reconstruction.
articles.abstract: After years of taking losses on home insurance, insurers are increasingly making homeowners responsible for repairs and reconstruction.
articles.lead_paragraph: PALMETTO BAY, Fla. — Charles R. Williams stood near the glass sliding doors in his home south of Miami and pointed out parts of the ceiling and walls that had crumpled after Hurricane Andrew ripped open the roof 15 years ago.

articles.headline: Europe Fears That Meth Foothold Is Expanding
articles.snippet: The number of countries in Europe reporting seizures of methamphetamine more than doubled in recent years.
articles.abstract: The number of countries in Europe reporting seizures of methamphetamine more than doubled in recent years.
articles.lead_paragraph: JESENIK, Czech Republic  The methamphetamine epidemic is not just a scourge of the American heartland. It has a powerful foothold here in the heart of Central Europe. Home meth labs are sprouting up all over the country to produce this cheap, potent drug using the pseudoephedrine found in common cold medications.

articles.headline: Plan Increases Role of G.I.’s in Iraq Training
articles.snippet: Commanders hope to shift more of the security burden in Iraq to the Iraqis without giving up gains U.S. troops have made, officials said.
articles.abstract: Commanders hope to shift more of the security burden in Iraq to the Iraqis without giving up gains U.S. troops have made, officials said.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 — With violence in Iraq on the decline and a quarter of American combat brigades scheduled to leave by July, commanders plan to give the remaining brigades an expanded role in training and supporting Iraqi forces, according to officials involved in a confidential military review of the next phase of the American troop deployment.

articles.headline: A Bad Loan by Any Other Name
articles.snippet: Chalk up one more term from the credit debacle.  Nina loans - an abbreviation that stands for “No income, no assets.”
articles.abstract: Chalk up one more term from the credit debacle.  Nina loans - an abbreviation that stands for “No income, no assets.”
